datafield.subfield: Anthems; known as the Gostling manuscript :
Use: Unrestricted, for either reading room or classroom use

Franklin B. Zimmerman, Anthems of Purcell and Contemporaries in a Newly Rediscovered 'Gostling Manuscript,' Acta Musicologica Sonderdruck I-II, vol. XLI (Basel: BaÌ⁸renreiter-Verlag, 1969), pp. 55-70 (with plate, and full list of contents). For a facsimile, see The Gostling Manuscript (Austin: University of Texas Press, 1977).
Purcell Society subscription flyer, December 1901. Handwritten Letters. Articles and tearsheets from Musical News. Thematic index to Gostling Ms.

Contains sixty-four anthems by Henry Purcell, John Blow, and their contemporaries, principally for solo voices and mixed chorus with string orchestra, orchestra, or continuo. Handwritten Letters. Articles and tearsheets from Musical News. Thematic index to Gostling Ms. Compiled by bass soloist John Gostling, a friend of Purcell. The first twenty-six items are on pp. 1-205 counting from the front of the manuscript; another thirty-eight items are on pp. 1-213 numbered from the back of the volume; pp. 205 and 213 share a leaf. Contemporary alphabetical indexes of each half are written on the respective front pastedown.

MS 3327, Container 85: William Gostling (1696-1777) from his father; owned in the early 20th century by William Kennedy Gostling, and a Miss Gostling of Folkestone, Kent; sold at Sotheby's, London, 24 July 1935 to an anonymous owner; acquired by New York booksellers James F. Drake, Inc.; purchased by the University of Texas in 1967. Bibliography: Franklin B. Zimmerman, Anthems of Purcell and Contemporaries in a Newly Rediscovered 'Gostling Manuscript,' Acta Musicologica Sonderdruck I-II, vol. XLI (Basel: BaÌ⁸renreiter-Verlag, 1969), pp. 55-70 (with plate, and full list of contents). Binding (England 17th /18th c): Full medium-brown tanned calfskin over paper boards. Straight (?) caps, tight back over sewing supports, edges deckle. Blind-tooled concentric frames (three), front and back covers, stain decoration (sprinkling) outer- and innermost areas (f/k/a Cambridge panels or Cambridge binding), blind-tooled corner pieces, three-line blind tooling across spine; no title. Sewn on raised cords laced on boards (six bands, four laced on supports discernible, sewing not visible). Endleaf components: front tipped fold off-white handmade laid paper making pastedown, free endleaf; back same. Repaired (reback, brown tanned goatskin, machine-made endbands stuck on, inner joint repairs).
Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Collection.
